ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Knowledge on microeconomics.
Basic economic skills and intuition.
I developed economic analytical skills as well as mathematic econ skills.
I learned how to process broad lecture information and apply it to questions.
I not only learned the course material, but have come to think about the ways humans make decisions with new vocabulary and in more quantitative ways.
Everything there is to know about introductory microeconomics :) and its applications in the real world.
I learned a lot about microeconomics and the various ways prices affect the behavior of agents in a market.
I gained a basic understanding of microeconomics.
Learned skills for economic analysis of markets, government intervention, taxation, firm behavior.
I learned about how to make economics predictions in areas such as supply/demand, producer theory, monopoly, pricing decisions, and more.
I learned basic economics in addition to learning how to apply my knowledge to newer and more complex problems.
I've developed an understanding of the ways people make decisions, as well as the ways competitive markets function efficiently.

I learned so much about the world of microeconomics  from consumer and firm decisions to market failures in a way that I'd never before had the opportunity to do. Engaging with this course also allowed me to learn what it's like to navigate a gigantic college lecture in a relatively comfortable, introductory-level environment.
Great introductory course to microeconomics, especially for someone with no previous economics experience. Also cool to understand why things work in the real world.

solid understanding of many aspects of microeconomic theory.
we start with how supply and demand influence price, and build that towards looking at how market structure, tax, subsidies, prices of related goods, costs of production, budget, etc etc influence these too. we build towards, at the end, looking at different models to evaluate how 'good' a given policy or economic outcome is. 

it's a really informative class that provides a useful way for thinking about and actually understanding the economy, the influence of policies on people's lives, and the positive and negative outcomes that the free market (and other types of markets) lead to. essential information for anyone interested in economics or even just politics, whether in a casual or professional sense. probably one of the few classes where you'll learn things that will be relevant and useful for the rest of your life.
A substantial level knowledge of microeconomics, with practice in math skills and problem solving.
I learned basic microeconomics skills.
I now better understand how the market works and how firms and consumers act accordingly
Basic ECON knowledge. Supply and demand. Profit and utility maximization. Lots of graphs. Derivatives. Carbon dividends.
Little to Nothing; I couldn't take much away from the class. Felt expected to teach myself the material outside of class rather than ever receiving any sort of education. Not happy!
I learned economics skills.

In this course, I mainly learned about supply and demand, consumer theory, producer theory, as well as the basics of game theory. I also feel like my analytical skills improved especially when reasoning through and interpreting graphs.
I gained a great foundation of microeconomics (consumer theory and producer theory)
I gained knowledge about microeconomics.

Although I had taken economics in high school, I felt like this course allowed me to develop the mathematic side of economics which I had never learned, allowing me to make sense of the graphs that I observed.
You can expect to develop a basic understanding of markets and microeconomics. Builds a good foundation for future economics courses and just economics in life in general.
introductory microeconomics! consumer theory, producer theory, market failures, etc.

Fundamental basis of microeconomics- how different firms operate in different market conditions 
mathematical - graphical and algebraic skills
I learned to think critically in terms of mathematics.
I learned introductory economics. Crazy. But no, seriously, I didn't take this for any requirement and I do feel like I got a lot out of it. I knew nothing about economics before.
Learned basic microeconomics

I gained knowledge of basic economic concepts and the vocabulary to talk about them. I learned to connect intuition, logic, and quantitative elements to solve problems applicable to real world scenarios.

You can expect to learn the same concepts from AP Microeconomics, but on steroids. This class goes into much more detail and way more quickly - stuff covered beyond AP concepts include the Cournot Duopoly, Pareto Principles, types of taxes, social welfare functions, calculating one's aversion or favor of risk by using expected utility functions, isoquant and isocost and how firms use them to maximize profit, ceteris paribus, etc. Even if you're not an Econ major, I highly recommend taking this class as these fundamental concepts are important to understand in life.
I learned a plethora of different Economic concepts, and I learned how to apply what I learned in lecture to more difficult questions on problem sets and exams that require critical thinking.
I developed skills in applying logical thinking about market outcomes to mathematic equations and I acquired a lot of new knowledge about the inner workings of the economy.

Interactions of supply and demand in different market structures: perfect competition, monopolistic competition, monopoly, oligopoly, monopsony. Ability to understand basic economic interactions of price and quantity in world around me, like what causes a surplus vs a shortage, when and why taxes are necessary, what causes costs and benefits to arise in specific economic decisions.
Understanding of microeconomic principles, firm and consumer decision processes.
I have gained a rough understanding of the concepts and applications of buyers and sellers coming together in a market. I can now express concepts through economics terminology.
Foundations of economics (supply and demand, producer theory)
I really enjoyed this class because I was able to learn a lot about microeconomics. It was my first time taking an economics class, and I found it really interesting.

I learned how to use supply and demand curves, marginal analysis, and various market structure graphs to model the processes of different markets. This course teaches the relationship between consumers and producers in market models.
I learned how to analyze things from an economic perspective and learned the basic of measuring economic principles.

Coming into this course, I knew nothing about intro micro. I learned a lot about the behaviors of firms and individuals and how different decisions can make an impact on these behaviors. I greatly improved my economics-based critical thinking and problem-solving.
Basic knowledge about Microeconomics and how firms and individuals make decisions
I learned a lot about the different basic economics concepts, specifically different markets and how different factors impact each market.
My knowledge of microeconomics highly increased
I gained basic insight into the foundations of economics for the first time, and developed the ability to better understand trends and shifts in the modern market.
I understand a variety of markets now because of this class. It goes in-depth about consumer and producer theory. I think it's essential to learn these topics.
I gained a lot in insight into consumer theory, producer theory, different market structures and some other topics towards the end of the semester.
Insight into supply and demand, different market structures, and consumer/producer decisions
A basic understanding of microeconomics concepts like supply and demand, consumers and producers, and markets.
Loved this course! Although the material was dry sometimes, it was fascinating to learn about how the economy really worked. A must take here at Yale.
introductory microeconomics - supply and demand, consumer theory, producer theory, market failures and social welfare
Learning about microeconomics and problems on an in depth level
Elementary economics and critical thinking.
great introductory understanding of microeconomics and how to think like an economist

I got understood the basics of microeconomics and their applications in the real world. I also understood the importance of understanding the basics before the complex concepts, since micro is definitely a class that heavily builds on the first couple weeks of material.
I developed an understanding of microeconomics under different categories (like supply and demand, monopolies, monopsonies, price ceilings/minimum wage, duopolies, and Pigouvian taxes/subsidies).

I learned a lot about econ and its importance in our everyday lives. I havent taken a math/qr class in a few years since high school and this wasnt the best option for my first math/qr class but it wasnt the worst.
I learned key micro econ topics and skills
I never taken micro ever but this course provided me a lot of introduction to the field of microeconomics, and economics in general
I learned about supply/demand theory, marginal utility/cost, elasticity, indifference curves, Pareto efficiency/dominance, market structures, etc.
I developed an understanding to the introduction ideas of microeconomics.
I developed both an understanding of introductory microeconomics and the limits of the discipline as a whole.
Time management, how to work in a large lecture
math, economic analysis, thinking about the economy differently
A very thorough understanding of basic microeconomics, the ability to differentiate and evaluate different markets, economic intuition
I learned the important concepts of introductory microeconomics and felt like I gained a good sense of economic intuition for new concepts.

I learned a lot about the mechanics of micro 101. I already knew some of the concepts through intuition, but it was very useful to learn how to actually work the problems formally. Also thinking on the margin  very useful mindset to get into, both in economics and in life.
Basic microeconomics, how to think like an economist
I learned how to properly use analytics in the real world related to economics.
This class was my first introduction to economics, and I feel like I gained a very solid base of knowledge in roder to move forward in studying microeconomics.

This was my first ever Economics class, and I was able to learn about many different concepts. I realized microeconomics had a lot to do with math and creating graphs. I realized that I was a big visual learner, at least when it came to Economics.
Information on microeconomics.
interpreting information
I learned a lot about microeconomics and the way our world functions
basic microeconomics concepts
Fundamentals of microeconomics: consumer and producer theory, market structures.
Learned about basic microeconomics topics (supply, demand, taxes, monopoly, game theory, etc).

Although I took AP Microeconomics, I still chose to take Econ 115 to gain a more comprehensive overview of the knowledge, and I felt like this course provided me with that. I learned more of the algebra behind the graphs and the shifts, and seeing the math really helped me understand the intuitive concepts I had learned before.
Econ is super insightful into the way firms work and strategic thinking in the market world. Cormac also helped to connect our material to real-world problems and events.
learned a bit about theoretical econ.

Economics is a misunderstood field of study. If you want to enter the world of business, finance, or entrepreneurship, realize this class will not directly relate to any of those fields, although it can provide useful background information that could be applied to those fields. I learned how scarcity creates the need for economies and explored how firms and consumers make decisions in the face of scarcity, which requires simple algebra, graphs, and understanding the base concepts that are necessary for answering the more challenging questions
I learned how to think as an economist and how to always consider outside factors when using simplified graphs to model economic phenomena.
Market equilibrium, how firms in different markets decide what quantity to produce/price to set, how consumers make decisions, effects of taxation, finding efficient allocations.

The class is focused on introductory microeconomics so we started off with supply and demand. We covered producer and consumer theory and about different producer models. We also learned how to solve for optimal consumption and optimal production.

This was my first econ course and I learned so many basics about supply and demand and producer and consumer theory. I developed more insight into how markets work and the differences between monopolies and perfectly competitive markets.
How to think logically, quantitatively, graphically, and how real world insights (such as human behavior) affect situations economically.
I acquired a much better understanding of economics and feel more prepared to understand the world as an economic consumer.
microeconomics
I learned a lot about the basics of microeconomics. This was also my first big lecture so I learned a lot about how to learn in these settings.
This was my first econ course, so I learned all of the basics of econ. I also learned how to take notes in a large lecture class and study for my first college exams.
I learned essential components of microeconomics and learned about supply and demand, consumer and producer theory, game theory, and a wide variety of other topics.
I learned how to apply quantitative skills to social issues.
I developed a better understanding of the basic principles of Microeconomics. I also developed a better ability to think like an economist in all aspects of life.
Introductory understanding of microeconomics

I learned all about introductory economics in this course. As someone who has never taken an economics course before, this was a good course to develop basic introductory economic skills and knowledge, setting me well up for future economics classes. I learned about the market's relationship with the government, consumers, and producers.
I really learned how to apply concepts learned in class to larger problems in exams and in life. I think this is a great skill to have because it was less of memorization and more of application.
Supply/demand, Taxes, Externalities, Market Inefficiencies, Market Structures
Basic microeconomics, introduction to game theory, externalities
I learned a lot about basic micro. It was a useful course not only in teaching the content, but telling students about the economics not covered in the course; the missing pieces.
This class taught me the basics of microeconomics as well a crucial logic and problem solving skills.
I learnt economic skills and was able to understand questions well
Taking economics for the first time shifted the way I think about certain things, a positive intangible.
Critical math thinking skills in dense theoretical concepts
I gained new insights to many economic concepts.

I learned some of the basics of microeconomics and how to think like an economist and how to use quantitative analysis to understand certain economic topics. I also learned a lot of intuition on these topics.
Learning how to retain information from a lecture based class
I gained insight into basic theories of microeconomics and how to understand them through graphs.
A deep understanding of Microeconomics.
I learned the basics of economics and how to evaluate some fiscal values.
It was a great introduction to the major ideas of economics. Though it was challenging, it's was easy to find help and support.
I learned the foundations to microeconomics and the principles to firm decision making.
How to think like an economist and problem solve
I developed the ability to better understand phenomena through graphs, logically, and algebraically.
I learned so much about introductory microeconomics, from graphs, to algebraic expressions, to concepts.
Knowledge of economic thinking and marginal analysis. Taking a general understanding of balancing benefits and costs to learn about the real world.
Knowledge on microecnomics.
I had taken Economics in the IB and new I was interested, but this course was a good opportunity for me to further my interest by exploring microeconomic perspectives in depth.
I learned introductory micro economics skills such as consumer and producer theory as well as the effects of various variables like taxes.
I have never taken microeconomics so I gained all of the mechanical and conceptual knowledge I have on the subject from this class.

This course has provided me with a strong introductory knowledge to the field of microeconomics, including the ways to measure of optimal allocations of resources, with concrete insights on consumer and producer theory and foundational economic laws.

I learned how firms and individuals interact with each other depending on supply and demand for goods and services, in addition to government intervention 
I also learned how scarce resources in our world are allocated efficiently
Learned a lot about basic economic theorems.
I developed problem solving skills and the ability to complete and understand complicated problems.
Analysis of graphs, applications of economics

I developed quantitative reasoning learning both theory and application of intro microeconomics. I had 0 knowledge coming into this course, but I learned basic microeconomics that help me understand day-to-day transactions and business decisions of consumers and producers.

The ability to think like an economist and gain a better understanding of the world we live in from an economic perspective. I also learned to independently expand on what I learned in lecture in order to make breakthroughs in my learning.
econ thinking
Algebraic skills and insights into theoretical models.

I learned in great detail how individual markets in firms interact with consumers and other competitors in a variety of disparate economic settings. I learned how to economically graph these concepts and to think both conceptually and computationally.

I had not previously studied any economics thus this was a very interesting lecture to attend. I feel as though I began to develop certain skills in understanding how different situations were not only played out but manipulated in different types of economies. I believe it has been a great help in my knowledge of understanding the fundamentals behind economics in general.
Learned about micro
I learned about microeconomics and the building blocks of how economics and markets interact.
Analysis of behavior from consumer and firm sides
A very strong understanding of fundamental microeconomics, including an intuitive sense as well as a graphical and numerical grasp.

Understanding of the key concepts of microeconomics. 
How to make shutdown decisions.
Factors to decide enter-exit.
I learned how to think like an economist and apply topics to real world examples.
Time management, a background of economics to expand upon and an ability to take notes in a lecture-like setting.
I learned about producer and monopolistic theory.
A great understanding of microeconomic principles and basics.
Improved quantitative abilities and explored economics in a lecture atmosphere.

I learned how to think like an economist, which is something the instructor really stressed because of the possibilities that this may be our only economics course or it may be an introduction to more courses. Learning the strategies of basic economics will be useful to apply in later economics classes. I developed a routine of studying that proved very effective, and I can apply the strategies to other classes. I also found office hours and peer tutoring helpful and was able to develop a routine of getting the help I needed that way.
A basic understanding of economics, including supply and demand, price equilibriums, and factors influencing logical decision making
Learned about the basics of microeconomics and how to think like an economist.
I have gained knowledge related to economic analysis, market trends, and economic behavior.
I learned about basic economic principles and how to orient myself in different markets.
I learned theories about how and why producers and buyers buy and sell at certain rates and quantities.
knowledge about economics
Fundamentals of micro Econ - graphical representations of Econ phenomena, a big picture understanding of markets and why firms do certain things.

The insights I gained from this course allowed me to understand the basic principles which dictate consumption and production. Especially interesting was the coursework about externality and government intervention in the economy. Also, learning about imperfect competition cases helped me get a grasp for the real world of economics.

I feel this class developed my self-discipline, as since lectures were posted online I knew I didn't have to attend lectures, but I seemed to retain material better when I attended in person, so I had to try and hold myself accountable and keep going.

I gained a very nuanced understanding of many basic principles of Microeconomics. These skills and the knowledge I acquired have, even in the days shortly after the course, changed how I think about current events and the economy around me in my everyday life.
Logical thinking
I learned how to do basic economics.
I learned how to participate in a lecture class.
I learned a whole lot of microeconomics!
This is an intensive course to learn about the fundamentals of microeconomics. I was able to learn different concepts that play role in our markets and different kinds of markets.
Extremely much! Great foundations within microeconomics. Consumer and producer theory, graphing, economic intuition, how to think like an economist more generally. Fantastic course!
A great introduction to economic concepts and how to think like an economist.
better understanding of supply and demand in different types of markets, labor economics, etc

I learned more about the allocation of scarce resources and how the decisions of each individual form have an effect on the economy. I also learned how consumers decisions can have an impact on the economy.

I learned fundamental concepts in microeconomics and how they could apply to real life, which was an interesting perspective I had never considered much before because I had never taken economics courses.
I learned the insights, information, and skills that will function as the basis of my knowledge in economics as I continue studying further in the field.
Basic microeconomics, mainly graph interpretation
Understanding markets, supply +demand, prisoner's dilemma, Externalities, and taxes.
I came in with very little knowledge of economics, and I came out with a much better understanding of both consumer and producer theory.

I gained a lot of knowledge by taking this class. Some of the skills and insights I developed by taking this course is how to deal with large lecture courses such as studying and learning the good study habits. I also learned how to do time management and leaned more about economics.
A decent understanding of basic Microeconomics.

This was my first class at Yale with official PSets, so I learned to space my week out to do them. I had also never taken an econ course, so all of the principles taught were new to me. I would say though, the biggest skill I acquired was learning how to ask for help. The course made getting help so accessible that it pushed me to develop the courage to do so.
An insight into the basics of economics forming a foundation of my knowledge. Most importantly, I used the class to gain an understanding into whether I hope to pursue economics

From this course I learned  basic economic concepts that I feel I will be able to apply to anything I pursue in the future (related or unrelated to economics).  I think that Intro to Microeconomics is the perfect course for any undergraduate student no matter what major one may pursue. This course teaches you to think critically about cause and effect, which is a skill that can be applied outside of economics. Professor Cormac O'Dea especially made this course fun and worthwhile!

I learned a lot about the basics of microeconomics because which is great because this is what I want my major to be in. This course does a great job making sure that you can understand not just what work you are doing but what it means in real life scenarios.
I developed skills that allowed me to think critically and analyze problems in an efficient manner.
I learned how to apply theory to real-world situations and extend formulas and graphs beyond what was taught in the lecture.
This class is a very good intro to microeconomics, and you learn certain skills such as logicing through cause and effect and thinking on the margin.
I learned some selected topics in introductory economics.
Thinking like an economist, applying mathematical models to understand and predict human behavior and resulting effects on the economy
Mathematical concepts related to microeconomics
This course covers a lot of useful information and helps to set a good ground for macro. In fact, It goes twice faster as I have taken before in high school. I recommend.
fundamentals of microeconomics
How to analyze economical concepts graphically and computationally.
Analytical skills and connecting mathematical explanations to the real world
I learned the fundamental microeconomics principles and their most general applications.
Knowledge of how consumers and firms make economic decisions.
How economists think and also how to intuitively understand concepts before applying math to them.
I learned basic microeconomics.
I learned the basic principles of microeconomics.
I learned the basic introductory microeconomics knowledge.

I learned a lot about how firms and consumers make decisions. I feel that my own perspective as a consumer has changed a lot since taking this class: I think about sunk cost fallacy, price discrimination, etc. when making purchasing decisions or understanding the economy. I feel that I have learned a lot about economics in general.
basic microeconomic principles and analysis
I was able to develop an understanding of basic economics and I hope to apply it to the real world.
I came into microeconomics with zero knowledge of the field and walked away with a good baseline of knowledge and confidence to take future economic courses.

I learned a lot about Economics and the idea of Economics. I previously did not even know what Economics was  such a big term! Now I have a better idea of it and all the different fields, and about basic economic concepts and skills.
I found new knowledge for peactical implementation in my future research work in Finance.
I learned a lot about the basics of Microeconomics as well as some very helpful formulas and concepts.
I developed knowledge in introductory microeconomics in this course.

Learning this course was foundational to my knowledge of microeconomics and Im grateful I had the opportunity to learn this material. I learned how to properly study for exams and apply myself in class.
Microeconomic! Learned a lot as someone who has never taken economics before.
I developed a strong understanding of fundamental economic theorems to be able to think like an economist.

Having never taken an economics course before, I gained a very strong foundation in microeconomics. In addition to learning all the fundamental skills taught in the course, I also think that I started to build my economic intuition, which I began to be able to apply in newer and more difficult scenarios towards the end of the semester. Furthermore, I generally learned what it's like to take a large lecture course in college as my largest class size throughout all of high school was 20 students.
I learned how to think about everyday problems with the logic of marginal analysis. I think this was the most important aspect of introductory economics for me.

Foundational understanding of microeconomics and how various types of firms and people interact
Critically thinking on problem sets/exams to solve content that hadn't been taught in class
I learned all the foundations of microeconomics.
Basic economics: terms, formulas, etc. Applying economics to real world examples, such as political theory.
I learned about the basics of economics, including supply, demand, consumer theory, producer theory, taxes, subsidies, monopolies cournot duopolies and more.

This course helped me develop studying skills as well as time-management. I also gained insight about how to adjust to learning in environments with many students. The lecture format at first challenged me so this course helped me strategize how to cope with this difficulty.

I learned the basics of microeconomics and how to "think like an economist" in applying critical thinking to real world evaluations. I learned how to apply the basic and rudimentary theories of economics to situations I might encounter in practical economics.

Aside from the fundamental knowledge of ECON115, I think I learned a lot on how to study and better understood how best I can understand material. For me, I realized that I should review material learned in class again after class, instead of leaving review for when I studied for exams. This 115 class also did a great job connecting the material taught in lecture to the real world, giving examples as to how our knowledge was applied and relevant outside of the classroom.
I learned microeconomics from a quantitative perspective. I studied econ in high school, but the curriculum back then was too focused on policy evaluations without much quantitative modeling.
This was my first ever big lecture course so I learned how to manage the course load and a different style of learning than Im used to.
Without any prior knowledge of microeconomics, I learned lots about the nitty gritty of the economic world and how it applies to real life.
I learned a strong basis of economics that i feel will be very helpful for future classes I take.
I learned how to study in a big lecture and stay engaged.
How economists view the world. I was introduced to another perspective of how our economy works. The knowledge that has stuck with me the most are the various graphs throughout the course.
Elementary jargon for economics and tools to further develop my understanding of the ebbs and flows of a free market economy with varying levels of competitiveness.

I developed an important base knowledge pertaining to both consumer and producer theories as they relate to microeconomics. Specifically, I obtained knowledge of equations and theorems that can be used to evaluate economic problems.
Great, strong, fundamental introduction into intro economics.
I learned about supply and demand, consumer economics, producer economics, what firms do, different market scenarios such as monopoly, perfect competition, oligopoly, Cournot duopoly and so on.
Quantitative reasoning skills, basic understanding of economics
Thanks to this course, I was able to develop an economic-like mind. I applied myself to the material and can carry concepts such as opportunity cost into the real-world.
Theoretical understanding of basic microeconomics

One of the biggest things I realized was the academic prowess of Yale. The curve of the first exam really caught me by surprise, and I learned a lot about where my previous studying techniques weren't cutting it. It was a big eye opener, and really set me up for more successful learning, studying, and test taking for the rest of the semester.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Unnecessary difficult vocab for things that can be explained much easier.
Larger lecture class made it difficult to stay engaged at times, but office hours was very helpful.

I appreciated the structure of this course, and enjoyed the lectures. I think one way that it could be improved would be by slowing the course down (spending more time on certain topics such as game theory).

I think it would be helpful for the OH for this class to occur more often. I also think it would be helpful for sections to be longer than 50 minutes because my group often did not complete the section questions. I also wish this class took the PSETs more into account.

I think the professor and lectures are excellent. The material is very well organized and expectations are made clear. I don't think there were any weaknesses. I wish problem sets had comments about why points were taken off and for what questions.

Strengths: lots of real-life application and examples; put together in a way that maximized my learning; wonderful that the lectures were recorded so that I could rewatch if I missed something.

Weaknesses:
This course is very well structured and organized to give students without any experience a solid introduction to economics.

I wish there was more discussion of social, environmental, and political impacts of economic systems, but perhaps that is included in a future class. The class was well structured and there was a clear line from lectures, to p-sets, to exams.

This course was insanely well designed overall. Great teaching by Cormac. A ton of office hours throughout the week. Consistent due dates. Multiple review sessions for exams. Great discussion section leaders. No complaints.
The strengths of this class are that there are a lot of resources available for our success. There are many office hours and lots of practice exams.

Strengths - organized, help available to students
Weaknesses - can be fast-paced at points

The course was very fast-paced, which means that it was sometimes difficult to keep up with the material. However, the course directors made external resources incredibly and fantastically accessible  peer tutoring sessions, TA office hours, and professor appointments were my lifelong throughout the course. If I was struggling with the material, pace, or class as a whole, I felt as though I almost always had somewhere to turn to.

Strengths: Cormac is an amazing professor who truly cares about his students, even in such a large lecture class. 
Weaknesses: Lectures sometimes started to become a bit boring towards the end. Perhaps more engaging activities or videos to break up the lecture could make it easier for students to stay actively engaged the whole class. Also, the TFs pretty much do not provide feedback on psets, and then all of sudden on the exams, they take off points for things that were never pointed out earlier.

strengths: encourages us to reflect on and understand the things we learn, rather than memorize them. concepts are intuitively explained in multiple ways. the workload is light but selective, and i feel that the homework actually helped me learn. learning in a large lecture room was fun and definitely an important experience. useful and interesting material. massive team involved in teaching, so you can easily get support.

weaknesses: the sections weren't always useful. lots of people got the answers to psets sort of given to them there, such that they were screwed for the exams. don't do that - make sure you understand the material taught in class and can do the questions independently. though you don't need to understand calculus at all, you need a SOLID understanding of graphs and quadratic algebra, so make sure your non-calculus maths is on point.

It was accessible since there were online recordings of the lectures that I could rewatch. The slides uploaded before class also helped a lot. The TFs were also available for help most of the week with lots of office hours. Overall, an introductory course with lots of resources.
It is very strong in teaching detailed mathematics behind microeconomics, but gets fuzzy in the conceptual part of the class. More focus on the theories behind lessons would be nice.

Strengths: how problem set solutions are posted after the deadline, problem sets and practice exams were helpful (along with their solutions), lecture
Weakness: I felt that some points on exams were taken off for things that we were not explicitly told to do/have in our answers

Strengths = ...

Weaknesses = not very insightful hard to grasp the material (in one ear right out the other) Felt like material was being shown rather than explained.
It's too big, I can't focus on class this is mostly mo problem.

Being able to take the class asynchronously was a huge plus. Additionally, the availability of problem sets with optional problems as well as past exams was very useful in studying for the tests. The class however did feel impersonal at times.

Strengths - great professor and teaching, balanced amount of work
weaknesses - exams consist of 25% of your grade, sections are very fast-paced with no room for questions
Feedback on psets would be nice! Or even just pset answers being released after the fact.
I thought it was taught well for the most part. I wish the professor did more example problems.

strengths: lectures were very easy to understand. also josh is the best peer tutor 
weaknesses: so many people talking during class, very distracting :(

Strengths: Pretty well taught, an amazing professor, a generous curve if you're just trying to coast (Although it is quite difficult to get an A), and an abundance of office hours. The PSets also only take an hour or two to complete.

Weaknesses: Often felt disorganized when it came to examinations, section often felt like it confused me more than it helped me

I found that this course had no weaknesses.

It was incredibly well structured and well taught, in a way that encouraged engagement of students. I also found that the discussion sections were incredibly helpful and allowed me to learn much more than without them.

Strengths: clear assignments, good lecturer, solid sections 
Weakness: slightly unclear grading policies (grade cutoffs)

I really enjoyed this class! Cormac was a wonderful and engaging professor, and his lectures were super fun to attend in-person, but it was possible to take this course asynchronously as well (lectures were posted online). Sections and office hours were very accessible, available, and helpful, and the availability of practice materials on canvas made reviewing for exams easy. Sometimes, psets were graded harshly/unclearly, and I felt as if I had to attend office hours just to know HOW to word my answers for full points, but otherwise, this course was great.

Strengths- very informative and interesting to learn about 
Weaknesses- not the most intuitive, very theoretical

I also think an outline of all the testable topics would have been helpful (such as a list on canvas to refer back to). I also feel that subtle nods to the calculus of the topics we are talking about every so often would certainly have helped with my understanding. Instead, this course ignored the existence of calculus and forced us to use a less comprehensive algebraic approach. While I understand that this course does not require calculus and focuses on high school level math, it would be very helpful to those who do understand calculus to see the relationship. He clearly cares about his students and wants to provide all students with a fundamental understanding of basic econ (not just for econ/finance bros, but for everyone even mildly interested in the subject). An immense strength of this class was the posting of lectures online. For economics specifically, this format was so helpful as I watched the online lectures many times: to take my original set of notes, but also to study for exams, or answer questions I had on specific segments that had been taught. A weakness of this class is, in my opinion, how the grades are calculated. As a first-year who took this class in my first semester, as many of my peers were as well, I was acclimating to the lecture environment, test format, and the consequence that the tests basically made up my whole grade. Based on the discussion I've heard surrounding this class, it is most discouraging for first-time economics takers or those who don't have much exposure to the field. Considering the demographic of the economics study as a whole, especially at an institution like Yale, I think this is one of the places where the potential for diversity in future economists is lost, as many students in their first semester and first year take a grade (based on three exams) as a message about whether or not they should pursue this field.

The amount of resources this course provides in terms of office hours and past materials, complements the lectures and sections in a very helpful way. The only weak point for me personally was the format of review sessions before midterms and finals, in which I didn't find myself very focused and the engagement of the TA quite restricted. If there were maybe more review sessions organized with limited capacity, for which students would sign up for, maybe like exam focused section style sessions, this would help maintain the collaborative aspect but keeping it efficiently focused.

Strength is that the lectures are recorded and are pretty attentive in-person. On days I was sick or just felt wrong, I could decide not to attend the lecture and just take notes off the recordings. But attending lectures in-person is much better than recordings, however, for both understanding and paying attention to the actual topic at hand. Weaknesses are that sometimes it's difficult to apply theory (lecture) to application (psets/tests). Because the lecture mostly focuses on theory and not really application, sections with TF is used to supplement application. However, there isn't a clear connection from theory to application even then, and I recommend reading the textbook to supplement learning. If one has only a bit of knowledge of economics or less, the textbook is more important than emphasized in the class. If you read the textbook, do the lectures, and attend the sections, you'll be set. Otherwise, you'll probably struggle even if you attend all the lectures and sections. I emphasize this.

The strengths of this course was the learning pace. I think the material was broken down by week nicely and flowed from week to week. I think one weakness of the course was the grading system. For me at least, the way in which the grades were broken down created an environment of high anxiety when exams were approaching. With such a high percentage of our grade being based on exams, there were moments when I felt like my priority was memorizing and regurgitating rather than understanding and applying. I wish that there were other opportunities for grades that go beyond exams and problem sets, especially since problem sets were such a small factor into our grades.

The lectures were very informative, and I also really enjoyed the ability to review them online without losing any material. This made it so I never felt behind in the course or that there was material that was inaccessible to me throughout the difficulties of the semester. Something that I wish would be improved upon is the structure of the sections. I found my section to be rather drab in its instruction, with the teaching fellow walking through the section problems for us to just observe, really. We once had a substitute teaching fellow, who came in prepared with slides to review the topics the section material would cover. This TF also led the section by having us do parts of the question on our own then checking our work and walking through the questions themself. I found this model much more enriching and beneficial to my understanding of the material, and I would recommend some standardization of the sections so all of them are led in similar ways.
The amount of TF's and office hours provide for amazing/exceptional resources and tools to use when struggling.

Strengths:
- I really loved the interactive aspects of the exercises we did in class. That really helped engage me. 
Weakness:
- Obviously, because it is a lecture, it's hard to engage in the class all the time. However, I think discussion sections can be more like review sessions instead of just doing practice sessions. I also did not enjoy the amount of side chatter in the classroom, even though Professor O'Dea repeatedly told students not to do so.

The course is probably well-designed for the majority of the student body, with ample resources for self-learning and reviewing. Peer tutors, teaching fellows, professors, etc. all work together to make sure no one is falling behind.

However, after going to one section, I found that the section was too slow and only scratched the surface of the material in classit was 20% as useful as the lecture, if not less when factoring in the one-hour opportunity cost. I wish there can be "streamed" sections with more advanced topics, instead of going over mathematics basics over and over again.
One strength of this course is that there is an abundance of resources including TAs, ULAs, old materials for review, office hours, and more to help facilitate learning.
The lectures are a bit fast-paced, but the material is well organized.
Cormac's explanations are really really goos, and I like that there is an online option in case you missed a class, it allows everyone to stay on track. Plus, psets are super helpful for learning.
the lectures are super engaging and the professor does everything possible to make sure people have learned.
I thought this class was great, there were ample resources and people to reach out to for help. Professor O'Dea was a great lecturer as well.
Better organization of class materials.
Some strengths is that the lecture is well prepared and matches the content on the exams. A weakness is the chaos in TA sessions, grading, etc because of how big this class is.

It is a very large course. I understand that for the sheer amount of freshmen who take ECON 115, it is necessary to have a large lecture, but for many people who have not been in a class of that size, I think it is a bit hard to adjust.

I felt that the main weakness of the course was the size, and I do not think the large lecture setting was the best way to learn a subject like economics. The course was improved by the large amount of available office hours and the accessibility of finding support from the instructors. I felt that another critical weakness of the course was the fact that we were not allowed to use calculators or have a formula sheet on exams, as I was then forced to spend more time trying to memorize formulas and mathematical equations than I did trying to actively understand concepts taught in the course.

Great lectures, structured, clear. Cormac is great. Sections were very helpful, and course was great considering how large it is. Could be improved by offering more challenge options (not like pset extra-questions) but rather real-world insightful questions.

Strengths: many office hours and peer tutoring

Weakness: I cannot ask individual questions at peer tutoring/office hours, especially during midterms, since there are so many students. Usually it is review and my answers won't get answered (cannot attend my TA's office hours due to schedule conflict).
well organized and well resourced.
Enjoyed the problem sets as they provided good questions that were challenging and made me think. I believe the lectures could allude more toward the difficult questions present on exams.

Strengths: good TAs and peer tutoring, lots of available help, interesting lectures, applicable problem sets.
Weaknesses: could be more real-world applications in lecture

The biggest strength of this course was definitely the huge amount of resources available to further understand the material. The psets were very good at filling in the holes of my understanding, the discussion sections were great practice for the more difficult questions of the course, and there was an enormous amount of office hours to ask questions. Also, with access to past psets and exams, there were limitless ways to prepare yourself for exams if you were willing to put in the work.

A weakness in my opinion is the lack of office hours soley designated to going over the optional questions on the PSETs. I think that this resource would have been a great motivator for many to do the optional problems.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: if you need an easy QR credit, there are better courses to take.
yes
Yes if you are required for your major.

Yes. It is an introductory course, and does a good job of offering a baseline introduction into the world of economics. I will definitely be taking more courses in the economics department after this.
No, I would not recommend this class. I do not think this class is worth taking if not required for a major. The class is not as engaging or interesting as I had hoped.
I would recommend this course because it provides useful basic knowledge, and I do not think it is overly stressful.
Absolutely.
I would recommend this course to any student without much experience with economics but wants to try it out.
I would recommend this as a part of a well-rounded education. I most likely will only take one more economic class during my time at Yale but I think its important to have economic knowledge.
Yes! It's a great way to see if you're interested in economics, and is very applicable to understanding real world economics.
Yes, because the course was well organized but also challenged me.
Yes, this class gives you a fundamental understanding of what economics is.

YES! Even for non-economics majors, introductory microeconomics is a great opportunity to learn about real-world phenomena through while practicing unfamiliar, large lecture skills (p-sets, professor communication, notetaking and attendance, etc.). If you're nervous about jumping into economics because you've never before taken it, DON'T BE! I hadn't taken economics before this course, but after completing the semester, I'm so excited to take more classes in the department. Beyond learning so much content, I've also learned so much about how to be the best learner I can be in this incredibly unique setting.
Yes, Cormac is amazing. Great intro class for those with no prior experience in economics.
absolutely. interesting, incredibly useful, pertinent.

I think this is a very solid introduction to microeconomics. It's a good Social Science credit for people who are math-oriented, but even then, the math is basic enough that it should be accessible to a wide range of students.
Yes, if they wanted to get a starting feel for economics this class is great.
I would recommend this course for anyone interested in learning about microeconomics.
Yes! I decided to try out Econ in college (after not being the greatest fan of it in High School) and this class has made me interested in Econ! I am now taking an Econ class next semester as well!
Only because it's a prerequisite for many majors.
Yes! The skills taught in class are important.

Yes. The concepts used in the class are versatile and the class is engaging enough. The recorder lectures also make it very easy to take the class at your own pace which especially nice for students with a heavier course load.
Yes! Although it's a lecture, it's really how much time you want to put into it. Sections and office hours are optional, but they do really help! Professor Odea teaches very well.
Yes! Especially if you go to the discussion sections those will help lots if you are feeling confused.
Yes, I think it's a good intro class.
yeah i think econ is good general knowledge to have in life no matter what your major is
If you're taking this class you probably need to take it. I would suggest this class over ECON 110 just because the curve is more generous in lectures. Love Cormac.

I would recommend this course to anybody interested in economics. 

Although I found it fascinating, I am aware that many people will not be as engaged in the topics, making it much more difficult to focus on the content. However, for anyone interested in economics, I would highly recommend this course.
Yes if it is a requirement and if you want some basic econ knowledge
Sure

Yes! You're probably taking it for a major requirement, but I'd 100% recommend econ 115 due to the wonderful professor, large community (very easy to commiserate with other students and make friends because of the 500 person class size), and interesting subject material.
I would if they are eager to learn about the basics of economics and how businesses really behave.

Personally, I thought it was challenging and difficult to lear. However, the professor was extremely kind and tried his best to help! The peer tutors are also fantastic so even though its hard you get through it with them.

Absolutely, I didn't take this for any requirement but I still feel like I got a lot out of it. As Cormac said, I learned how to think like an economist. I love learning different ways of thinking about the world and this was one of them. Also the course is very well formatted and there is lots of help!
Yes definitely. It is very interesting, and it gives you a new economic lens through which to view the world.
Only if youre interested in microeconomics.  Sure the workload is low but it is NOT the gut some people make it out to be.  You have to put in work to get an A-.

Yes! I think everyone should take ECON 115. It's a great introduction to a whole new (to me, at least) way of thinking about the world, and not too quantitative for people who don't consider themselves strong in math or science. It really is a logic/thinking class and will make you better able to understand the news and think seriously about current issues.
Yes, the things you learn are useful to know in life!
Yes. It serves as a great introduction to microeconomics.

Yes, I would recommend this course to another student because it was a very good introduction to microeconomics and as long as students study and review enough, the content of the course makes a lot of sense and is easy to study. The exams are very fair given the study materials and the office hours provided.

Yes, for the prereq and those who want an introduction to economics at Yale. If you have no prior experience in microeconomics, then you may struggle a bit more in this course. It is very math heavy. You need to be able to do more advanced algebra than what is advertised.
Yes, Cormac is a great professor, and intro micro is a good class to take for any major/student.
Yes. Good foundational class.
Yes. The course was engaging, the professor was great, and the work was minimal.
I would recommend this course to another student because it is a great first class at Yale. You learn a lot about economics in low stress environment.
I would recommend it because it is important to understand the basic concepts of Microeconomics.
I would recommend this course because it allows you to determine if you have economic interests. It also allows you to understand basic economic issues and discussions.
Yes, I really think its important to understand the economy and the actions that go into economic decisions.
Yes, if you like economics and are planning to take macroeconomics you should take this course
I would because it provides a good foundational knowledge.
Yes. The course provided a great foundation for economics, and was extremely informative, generally speaking.

Yes! I took this course as a sophomore intending for it to be an interesting 5th class since Id never taken econ before, and I really enjoyed everything I learned. I believe it is important to have a basic understanding of economics and this class will give you that. Cormac is a great instructor who is very understanding of our undergraduate experience and he is always willing to help in any way he can. The psets are the perfect level of work/challenge to help you develop your understanding of the topics introduced in class without overdoing it. I really recommend you take econ 115 over the seminar and definitely take it on sequence. I wish I took this class my first year fall since it is the perfect intro to Yale academia since Cormac is so understanding of the first-year experience especially.
I would recommend anyone to learn a little bit of economics. It introduces a lot of new ideas that everyone should understand. I would definitely recommend this course.
I would recommend this course to another student. I believe it is a great introductory class for someone who is curious about microeconomics.
Yes this class set up a great foundation for interest in more economics classes at Yale

Yes, I think it's a good way to see whether you enjoy economics, since it's such a large part of many majors here. Even if you don't end up majoring in anything econ-related, it's still good to know some basic concepts.

Yes! Take this course, very important for whatever field you're interested in. However, note that if you're looking for an A, the curve might make that very hard to doonly around 15% of ppl in the class will get an A bc of the curve.
youre probably taking it as a prereq or requirement
I think its important as a foundation for other economics courses
No, Unless you really enjoy Micro and or you need it for your major.
Yes, it was very engaging and I found the subject matter interesting.
Only if you need this course to fulfill a major requirement (for a major you're certain you want to major in) or if you're interested in economics, but otherwise, I wouldn't.
Absolutely. It's awesome

Yes, I would recommend this course. It gives you a solid foundation in microeconomics and also isn't too heavy of a workload. As long as you keep up with lectures and homework, studying for the midterms and final will not be super stressful.
Yes! It is a very good course if you have no prior experience in economics. It can be a bit hard to grasp the concepts at first though because the lectures go very quickly.

I would only recommend it if you can go to lecture or at least make sure youre caught up with watching the lecture recordings because one could really get behind on that. Optional sections also make it a lot more difficult to engage in class.
Yes, even though I already took micro in high school, I still learned a lot in this class like indifference curves and Pareto dominance, plus the class has a little bit more math than in high school.
Yes, it is a great way to introduce one to the field of economics in general.
Yes; covered a lot of material in a manageable way
yes! i think everyone should take this at least once. some may find it boring. some may find it too big of a class. but it is ultimately a good experience.

Yes, especially for those not considering the economics major but are interested in getting a better understanding of how the economy and our society works! Economics is such a huge real-world topic, so it's great to have a formal understanding of what is going on.

Yes, I would recommend this class whether you have knowledge of economics or if this is your first economics class! Professor O'dea laid everything out really clearly in lectures and discussion sections were great opportunities for practice.
Absolutely. Even if you don't pursue economics further, it's a great introduction to the basics while still going beyond "Econ 101-ism."
Yes, it is important if you want to go further in economics (unless you already know the material)
I would as its a great introductory course to Economics.
Yes, if they are interested in pursuing economics or need to take the course as a requirement
Yes. One of the best lectures I've taken at Yale. So interesting and fascinating.
This course is a great introductory economics course for those who are interested in the field but do not have prior experience.
Yes, good basis of general economics knowledge while not being too stressful or hard.
Yes! Professor Odea did a great job teaching it and it's a great way to explore economics.
Yes, gives you the basic fundamentals of economics
Yes, I think it serves as a concrete background for economic thinking. I found the material to be really interesting, and it has shaped how I view the world
Yeah, tbh I liked it. Thought it was interesting and useful to the real world.

Yes, if you want to gain a basic understanding of microeconomics. Taking this course doesn't mean you're selling outin fact, it's really important to try out everything that Yale offers and see what floats your boat. Would definitely take this if you do not have prior economics experience.
I would recommend the course to anyone at all interested in economics. I came in with zero economics knowledge, and the course gave me a pretty good idea of what economics is all about.
Yes, it's useful even if you don't plan on majoring in Econ. A lot of the knowledge is useful for just being an informed person in general, so I highly recommend everyone to take it.
I would for the reason that the lecture allows you to find more people to work with and more office hours to understand the material.
no if you have no understanding of econ. so many students have taken econ in high school so i felt very behind since this was my first time taking it.

Absolutely! Whether you're interested in pursuing economics as a major or not, it's a worthwhile course that teaches the fundamentals of producer and consumer theory, which are valuable regardless of the career path(s) you take.
Yes, the economics department at Yale is strong. The course is a good introduction to those who have no economics experience like myself.

Yes, especially if Cormac is teaching. Even if you're not interested in economics it is a great class to take since we are all consumers in this economy and it is good to understand how firms and consumers make decisions and its impacts. Low pset workload but you'll have to study a lot for the exams.

Yes if you need a QR, this is a major requirement or if you are just interested in economics. Don't allow this course to define your view of economics as a discipline, remember this is an introductory class.
Yes because it is a great intro to how economics work in broad sense. Also facilitated interest in the major and subjects like game theory.

Absolutely. It is facilitated so that even if you don't know anything about microeconomics you can learn but you also have to be willing to put in the effort as everything builds. Teaches you to think individually but also work collaboratively
yes to get a basic knowledge of the economy
Yes. Even if the student does not want to be an Econ major this course is excellent because it teaches you how to be a better consumer.

I would not recommend this course to another student because I felt that it was anti-intellectual and promoted rote memorization. We were taught to memorize formulas and graphs without understanding why they work or why they made sense. We often did problems that we were told would never show up in the real world, but the entire point of economics is to measure and assess the world.
Yes, I would, as I believe micro can be applied to many other areas of life.
Yes. This course covers a lot of important foundational topics and gives students a chance to explore economics if that is a field of interest.
Yes if you're interested in economics. No if you want an easy QR credit.

Yes; requirement for Economics major, changes way of viewing world, useful for any field

This is a good QR credit and though it may be frustrating at first, there is so much more to be gained from this class than a grade.

Yes as I believe it allows you to think in a different way then used to.

Yes, it is a fundamental course for the Econ major.
Yes as it is essential to learning the basics of economics
I would recommend it if anyone were debating majoring in economics.

Yes, a great course to take in your first semester.

I would recommend the course to anyone with an interest in learning about general economic principles.

Yea, its a nice way of entering Econ with the lovely Professor ODea

I also think every student at Yale should experience a course taught by Professor Cormac O'Dea.
a good intro to a college lecture class format + economic concepts

yes if they want to major in any humanities or social sciences course
I would recommend it only to get on the economics major track.

No since I was unclear about a lot of concepts at the end of the course.

I would recommend this course to all students to further their understanding of the world around them, through learning about economic principles via a great professor.

Yes, I would recommend this to anyone interested in exploring Econ.

Yes, for an introduction to economics it does its job
Yes, whether you do economics or not as a major a lot of the information is useful and applicable.

Yes. I think it is a nice introduction to microeconomics.
yes

yes -- even if you're not an econ major, I think this is probably a class that is good for most students to take. note that if you want an A you will have to study very hard

Yes
Yes!
If you are interested in econ, then yes.
100%. Great Professor, well-structured, interesting, and informative. Take this class because it helps you understand the world.

Yes, I think its a great intro course and very clear to follow. Theres also so much help between office hours and section that if you feel lost, its easy to ask for clarifications.

I would recommend this class to anyone that was interested in economics or wants to major in that field other than that I can not really speak to if you will like it or not.

The course is very informative and not terribly time consuming, and is a fantastic intro to a broad academic field.
Yes, it is a good introduction to microeconomics and even though it is a large lecture, there are many opportunities for extra help and improvement.

yes only if you're interested in pursuing economics.

yes, it is a good introduction for anyone interested in economics
Yes, a good introduction to economic concepts, manageable workload, and great instructors.
Yes, the workload isn't too high and the concepts are interesting.
Yes. It was engaging and curious even if you don't continue into economics
Yes, definitely. Cormac is wonderful.
Yes definitely! It was very interesting and is a useful topic to learn about even if you are not thinking of pursuing the major.
Yes I think it is very valuable to think like an economist.
I would recommend this course as it was a phenomenal introduction to economics.

I think leaning basic economic theory is important, so I would recommend that other students should generally take entry level economics

This course would be a very useful Knowles base for every student.

I would recommend this course to another student. It is applicable information that you can use for the rest of your life.
Yesespecially if Cormac is teaching it. Definitely doable even if you havent taken Econ before! A solid intro course if you want to learn some Econ without getting into the intense math.
Yes, this course is incredibly well organized. Professor ODeas lectures are clear and concise and there are so many resources outside of lecture to receive additional support.

I would recommend this course to another student because I had a great experience with it as my first big lecture course. I also think that Cormac did a phenomenal job as the instructor and that anyone would be able to learn a lot from him. I also feel that even for those who have no intention of pursuing economics past the introductory level, some of the skills and ways of thinking that this course teaches are useful for everyone.

Yes, I would. Even if the student is not going into an economics, business or finance field I would recommend this course. It gives insight into how American society works, as well as gives each student tools to make the optimal decisions when it comes to fiscal decisions.

Absolutely! Even if a student isn't interested in majoring in economics, Econ 115 provides a foundational understanding of how people interact in the market, which everybody should have as a tool (i.e. might help students make wiser decisions/save money).
I would recommend to anyone who needs this for a major requirement.
I would recommend to a student seeking to learn the basics of economics.
Yes! It allows a basic understanding of the course.

I would recommend this course to another student because I feel as though the workload was not extremely high and there were a lot of resources available, like office hours,  if you were struggling with course concepts.

I would recommend this course to anyone interested in starting economics or just curious about the subject as I was. I found the course to be as accessible as challenging, and despite taking no other economic classes prior to 115, I never felt disadvantaged or behind in my understanding. The material was presented in a very digestible and understandable manner, and I think it is a great course for anyone.
Yes. It is a good introductory course to help build your foundations in economics.

I would! I think the information we learn has great relevance to the world we live in. That's not to say that other classes aren't relevant outside of the classroom but I think this class makes such an effort to connect learning to real world events that it is definitely a worthwhile class.

I would recommend it if you are entirely new to economics. However, if you already have a solid background in econ (e.g. high school class), I strongly recommend you skip this class, even if the department's placement tells you otherwise. I was placed here because I got a 6 in my IB econ HL, and I took the class out of fear of missing anything. The course turned out to be 85% already-learned material and 15% new (mostly mathematical models that were only explained conceptually in high school; no concept was entirely new), and you may be better off just reading the notes from your friend taking the class. (There's a close-to-100% chance that at least one of your friends is taking the class.) Your time would be better spent elsewhere, especially for your first year.
I would recommend this course to others for a good basic introduction to economics.
Maybe. It depends on the student. I found this course engaging, but my peers often found themselves lost in the course material.

Yes, it's a great way to start learning econ. Cormac is a great professor and explains super well, the class isn't very hard, and if you do the psets, it's easy to get a good grade because you have plenty of practice.
yes! the professor is the sweetest person ever
Yes, I definitely would. The only thing I would say is that i have heard mixed reviews about the course depending on the professor and that might change others feelings about the class.
